This is a situation where Aspect-Oriented Programming might be useful 
after all.

This might be caused because the framework is doing some "Other Stuff" 
which is getting in the way of timing the actual execution time of the 
real work.  It may not be easy to extend the framework to get your 
numbers and still get "close enough" to the actual test execution to get 
meaningful numbers.

It might turn out that the test fixture setup is obscuring the actual 
execution time of the tests.  FOr example, if the fixture setup takes 
much longer than the actual execution of the Class Under Test.  This 
would make it difficult to get meaningful numbers, since the variance in 
the fixture execution time would obscure the actual test performance 
numbers.

In this situation, you could come up with some scheme to wrap the 
monitoring around the actual call to your Class Under Test, and avoid 
including your fixture setup in the monitoring.

AOP could be well suited for this type of task, because otherwise you 
would have to duplicate this monitoring code (or at least remember to 
duplicate a call to it) in each test method.

Then again, there could be a way to accomplish the same thing with Plain 
Old Java.  Maybe by routing all calls to the Class Under Test through a 
monitoring method.  This could take the class name, method name, and any 
params, then use some fancy reflection to invoke the method and gather 
the elapsed time.

-- Chad

Jim Dixon wrote:
> I haven't done very careful testing, but I certainly have noticed that
> the times reported by JUnit vary a great deal.
> 
> Running one simple set of tests just now gave me results in which 50%
> differences were common and more than one test took 3x as long from one
> run to the next.  So, sure, you can use JUnit for this sort of simple
> performance testing, but you should at least run the tests enough times to
> build statistical confidence in the results.
> 
> It didn't show up in these few runs, but I believe that I have noticed
> before that the first test reported a much longer than normal time --
> seconds rather than milliseconds.  So the order in which tests are run
> might introduce an effect large enough to render the results useless.
